answers.answer: What a bummer to have Lab mix ups. I bet you were relieved and thought you were home safe. You must be every irritated, I know I would be.Thyroid ultrasound can tell what type of nodule but it cant tell if cancer butUultrasound measure the size of the lobes of the thyroid gland. Thyroid nodules can located, measured, and examined to determine if they are solid or cysts filled with fluid. The shape and contour of each lobe can be outlined to see if it extends downward into the chest or towards the swallowing tube (esophagus) or windpipe (trachea).  it does not provide direct information about gland function. It can tell if the thyroid gland is enlarged, but can't tell whether the enlargement is due to overactivity or underactivity. Ultrasound cannot reliably distinguish between benign (not cancerous) and malignant (cancerous) thyroid nodules. However, certain features of a nodule, such as being a small simple cyst, may increase the chance of it being benign, whereas other findings, such as extension beyond the capsule around the thyroid gland, suggest malignancy.Thyroid fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is the only non-surgical method which can differentiate malignant and benign nodules in most, but not all cases.An open biopsy is more evasive, done by making a surgical incision through the skin to expose the thyroid gland.  Most doctors prefer FNA. However in some case both its best to have both done because FNA is not a 100%.  Plus with an open biopsy, they can check for cancer or do the biopsy while you are still out on the operating table.  If cancer is found, doctor will go ahead and operate or take the cancer or thyroid.  This save having to hover two surgeries.It is always best, better safe than sorry, to have all nodules checked for cancer, even the smallest have been known to have cancer.Good Luck!

Your US result is confusing me nearly as much as it is confusing you.  :-)  You said there is a small nodule but it looks like it's not really solid and not really cystic.  Which I would have to assume means the nodule is complex (or mixed).  A biopsy would be warranted if the nodule is complex (this is the type that I had and, although it was small at only 4mm, it was malignant - 95% AREN'T, by the way).Here are some good web sites about thyroid conditions and nodules:http://www.endocrineweb.com/http://www.cumc.columbia.edu/dept/thyroid/I'm just curious if there were labs run on you.  Thyroid nodules usually *don't* affect labs but where you are T1 Diabetic (autoimmune) I was wondering if they ran a thyroid panel with antibodies?Does your endo specialize in diabetes or thyroid conditions?  If it is diabetes, I would suggest a referral to one that specializes in thyroids.I have two different endos - one for my son's T1 diabetes and another for my daughter and my thyroid conditions.  Neither will mess with the other's area of specialty so they refer back and forth all the time.  Most endos in my area ONLY deal with diabetes, there are a very small number (and fewer good ones) who deal with thyroid conditions.

It could be.  I know that many of my doctors know each other from med school, having hospital privileges together, referring patients back and forth, etc.  I would hope that any referrals were for the best possible doctor for your condition but doctors are human too so there could be all sorts of reasons.Oops, don't tell the doctors that we're on to them that they are human, they will quit talking to some of us!  :-)
